Dear Ray:
Thank you for your temperate and explanatory letter of
June 5. I am sending photostats of it to the persons who received
copies of my letter of June 1 to Bill Harley.
o
My letter to Bill was prompted by the report I had re¬
ceived of the manner in which the NAEB Board had reached the de¬
cision to engage in independent TV production. It was presented to
me as being implemented unilaterally, without due regard far expres¬
sions of opinion from the TV members. This was my only area of con¬
cern. I do not oppose the decision itself; in faeO'I encourage the
experiment to determine the competence of NAE9 in regard to serving
unfulfilled TV program needs.41 I also do not question the authority of
the Board to decide the matter. 1 guess the only thing that really
bugged me was the fact that in view of the personalised nature of
NASB membership, the interest of those to be served by the action
was not solicited in the first instance.
Bill Harley is an energetic and intelligent administrator,
and I am with him all the way, I also respect your abilities and sin¬
cerity as Chairman of the TV Board. I am not alone, however. In
thinking that there is a “tight little group” aspect to board deliberations
and actions, and ! do not hesitate to speak my mind on matters about
which l feel strongly.
Sincerely
Richard S, Burdick
Executive Vice President and
